Linguistic analysis: The expert may have analyzed the language used in the claim to determine if it aligns with the typical language used by Democrats or if there are any inconsistencies or red flags that suggest the claim may be inauthentic.
Contextual analysis: The expert may have examined the context in which the claim was made, such as the political climate or any relevant events or statements, to assess the likelihood of the claim being true or false.
Fact: checking: The expert may have conducted fact-checking by verifying the specific statements made in the claim, such as whether Democrats have actually said that "even one hearing would be one too many" or if there is any evidence to support the claim that these propositions will affect millions of lives.
Source evaluation: The expert may have evaluated the credibility and reliability of the sources cited in the claim or the overall source of the claim itself to determine if it is trustworthy and authentic. This could involve assessing the reputation of the sources, cross-referencing with other reputable sources, or considering any potential biases or conflicts of interest.
